Thank you Ken.
No, i have no problem with concepts, I am rather trying to u=
nderstand the exact implementation of your hyperneat version, to code exact=
ly like that in my own parallel, GPU based implementation. 
Thanks again & =
best regards.
Nikolai

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Kenneth Stanley" <ksta=
nley@...> wrote:
>
> Nikolai, I think your question is essentially about vo=
cabulary.  You are asking whether the substrate would still be called an AN=
N if it contained non-sigmoidal nodes.  I believe no one has evolved such s=
ubstrates (i.e. with different activation functions), so I think it is a th=
eoretical question, but I think what you are saying is probably correct.  T=
he substrate does not need to be an ANN.  Of course, some ANNs do not use s=
igmoids (such as RBF networks), so just because the nodes are not sigmoids =
does not guarantee that it is not an ANN, but in some cases I would agree i=
t is not an ANN.  
> 
> I would be careful with the term "tree" because mos=
t graphs are not "trees," so I would not call it an "expression tree" unles=
s it really was somehow forced to produce trees or somehow output a tree as=
 the optimal result.  Whether it would be called "simple" is also probably =
a matter of opinion.  Generally, if there are many connections it may not r=
eally be simple, but it may be simple if the connection weights of those co=
nnections adhere to a simple underlying pattern.
> 
> I hope this answer he=
lps clarify some of your questions.
> 
> ken
> 
> 
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogr=
oups.com, "Nikolai" <ker_31_toluca@> wrote:
> >
> > --- In neat@yahoogroups=
.com, "Kenneth Stanley" <kstanley@> wrote:
> > >
> > > Nikolai, you have th=
e main idea right but the one aspect of your 
> > > description that I woul=
d correct is the idea that the substrate must
> > > be a perceptron.
> > 
>=
 > thanks Ken, as I understood, you call 'substrate' a final ANN that evalu=
ates the solution to the problem activating each node one by one where each=
 node uses the same activation function.
> > In a paper about CPPNs you say=
 that CPPN is not an ANN and this is why it is called 'CPPN', i agree. But =
when a CPPN produces weights for an ANN, the result (substrate) must be an =
ANN. If each node of the substrate is not perceptron type (i.e does not hav=
e a sigmoid activation function), then we can not call it an ANN, right ? I=
t could be called as some sort of an "expression tree"? And if it does not =
have many hidden layers, it would represent a simple (repetitive, symmetric=
al, etc) expression. A 'simple expression at large scale' if it is dealing =
with large number of connections. 
> > Please correct me if i am missing so=
mething.
> > Thanks
> > Nikolai
> >
>
